text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

JOSUE ZAPATA: Getting
in was one thing,

but then actually thinking,
"How am I going to pay for this?

It's another two years of
taking on more and more debt."

Unlike many of my colleagues who
are making six figures a year

before going to HBS, I
had six figures in debt
already from medical school.

My parents are both Colombian,
but both of my parents
immigrated to the United States.

My mom worked as
a Spanish teacher.

My dad worked as a manager
for Riverside County
where I grew up.

I really want to be a doctor
since I was a little kid,

to work in a job
where I'm doing work

that matters to a lot of
people that makes a difference.

I remember walking to
the hospital that day.

I'm checking my phone and seeing
that I had an email waiting,
"Oh, man.
I got in.
I can't believe it.
I can't believe I got into HBS."

Getting the fellowship
was crucial to being

able to attend by minimizing
the student loan burden
that I was graduating with.

I was able to really
pursue the career

that I was most excited about,
that I really wanted to do.

It let me let my passion
and my interest really

drive what I was going
to do going forward.

In America, we spend
17%, roughly, of the GDP

on health care for some of the
worst outcomes in the developed
world.

We're in dramatic
need of a revamping
of how we deliver health care.

We need a lot of people who have
big ideas, who are creative,

who want to do
significant things.

It's leaders who really
want to change the world.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
